what: Benthic composition and relief for horizontally facing imagery
title: TransectMeasure Workflow
text: Summary paragraph benthic imagery

title: TransectMeasure Workflow
text: developed simple approach characterise benthic composition complexity horizontally facing imagery (including stereo-BRUVs panoramic drop cameras), adapting existing standardised schema benthic composition (CATAMI classification scheme) benthic complexity 1. annotation approach rapid produces point annotation-level composition mean standard deviation estimates complexity, enable flexible modelling habitat occurrence fish-habitat relationships. set scripts ensure quality assurance quality control also provided.

title: TransectMeasure Workflow
text: Open program TransectMeasure welcomed blank screen (Figure 1). start analysis new set images: “Measurement” > “New measurement file” (Figure 2). Select “Read file …”. Locate folder images stored: “Picture” > “Set picture directory …” (Figure 3). Retake images unfocused blurry visibility low. stereo-BRUV imagery, left images annotated, panoramic drop camera imagery, top images annotated. load attribute file containing CATAMI habitat classification codes: “Measurements” > “Load attribute file …” > attribute file text file containing information necessary populating drop tabs classifying image (Figure 4). available download via CheckEM - ‘Schema downloads’.

title: TransectMeasure Workflow
text: Setting overlaying annotation points adding frame information set area interest: Hold shift left click four corners rectangle forms lower 50% image > Right click > “Add new area interest” (Figure 5). NOTE: accurately overlay area interest lower 50% image, can firstly overlay gridded dots rectangles (“Measurements” > “Dot configuration …”. Set accordingly: Gridded dots, ‘Dots across image’ = 1, ‘Dots image’ = 2 check “Overlay rectangles” box) use border rectangles guide. set points: “Measurements” > “Dot configuration …”. Set accordingly: Random dots, ‘Number dots’ = 20 (Figure 6). allow classify benthic composition according 20 randomly generated points lower 50% screen. need change settings first time use program computer. overlay points: Right click image select “Overlay dots” (Figure 7). name image appear table left image. subsequent images, can use “ctrl + ” add last used area interest overlay random dots (Figure 8). NOTE: annotate composite imagery, multiple areas interest need added corresponding images contained composite image. first area interest, points can added following steps detailed . remaining images within composite image, points can added existing points specifying new area interest, using “ctrl + right click + Add dots” > “Add existing points” (Figure 9). subsequent images, “ctrl + shift + ” overlay last area interest add random dots image. set frame information: image annotated, use “ctrl + t” automatically fill information stored image filename frame information fields (prompted review autofill information select “Yes”). NOTE: autofill information uses filename structure automatically generated exporting habitat images EventMeasure (Right click > “Save jpeg”. wish use feature, must either export images EventMeasure, name images match following structure - ‘OpCode_Period_ImageName’. TransectMeasure detect first 2 underscores separators parse information frame information fields. >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link (images/image5.png). Store image image server adjust path/filename/extension necessary. (Back top)(Next alert)>>>>> alt_text

title: TransectMeasure Workflow
text: Classifying benthic composition image Left click point display “Attribute editor” (Figure 10) Select biota lies directly underneath point “level_2” dropdown (includes benthos, un/consolidated substrate, open water unknown). point lands bait arm, bait bag part frame, select “unknown” “level_2” dropdown (Figure 8). Note: Zoom image analyse benthic composition closely adjusting “Zoom” value top left window holding ctrl key hovering cursor area like zoom . Continue populate dropdown (possible) “level_2” (.e. “level_3” > “level_4” > “level_5” > “scientific” > “qualifiers”). Available selections change depending value selected previous level. Select “Clear” reset dropdowns categories (Figure 10). dropdown “Code” automatically filled eight digit code possible categories selected point. Codes sourced Categories Australian Aquatic Biota database. >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link (images/image10.png). Store image image server adjust path/filename/extension necessary. (Back top)(Next alert)>>>>> alt_text

title: TransectMeasure Workflow
text: Classifying relief image Annotation relief need annotated separate TransectMeasure file (.TMObs), can set following steps defined ‘1. Load images attribute file’. separate schema relief available download via CheckEM - ‘Schema downloads’. set grid: “Measurements” > “Dot configuration …”. Set accordingly: Grided dots, ‘Dots across image’ = 5, ’Dots image’ = 4 check “Overlay rectangles” box (Figure 11). allow classify relief according 20 gridded points. need change settings first time use program computer. overlay grid: Right click image select “Overlay dots” (Figure 12). name image appear table left image. NOTE: composite imagery consists multiple images, gridded dot configuration can changed reflect multiple images. panoramic drop camera imagery containing four images, overlay 10 dots across image 8 dots image (Figure 14). Left click point display “Attribute editor” (Figure 15) Select relevant relief score whole rectangle “Relief” dropdown. 0. Flat substrate, sandy, rubble features. ~0 substrate slope 1. relief features amongst mostly flat substrate/sand/rubble. <45 degree substrate slope 2. Mostly relief features amongst flat substrate rubble. ~45 substrate slope 3. Good relief structure overhangs. >45 substrate slope 4. High structural complexity, fissures caves. Vertical wall. ~90 substrate slope. 5. Exceptional structural complexity, numerous large holes caves. Vertical wall. ~90 substrate slope. NOTE: ‘rectangle’ form benthos/substrate visible classified Relief (even open water makes majority grid). relief score rectangles entirely composed open water left blank. >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link (images/image11.png). Store image image server adjust path/filename/extension necessary. (Back top)(Next alert)>>>>> alt_text

title: TransectMeasure Workflow
text: Saving exporting TransectMeasure save work: “Measurements” > “Write file …” (Figure 16). creates *.TMObs file benthic classifications saved. export TMObs file: “Program” > “Batch text file output …” (Figure 17) following box appear: Double click right ✓ (“Data”) “Input file directory” row, locate folder *.TMObs file saved, “output file directory” specify folder location saving text file (Figure 18). Now select “Process”. generate output text file can processed using scripts included GitHub repository (see ‘Annotation summary quality control’). NOTE: order ‘OpCode’ ‘Period’ included final data outputs, need select option … . need per computer. >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link (images/image16.jpg). Store image image server adjust path/filename/extension necessary. (Back top)(Next alert)>>>>> alt_text

title: TransectMeasure Workflow
text: standard (rapid) assessment Benthic Composition _Relief _we recommend using : “BROAD” classification within Benthic Composition Relief. experienced analyst able annotate schema 200 images day. detailed assessment Benthic Composition (coral bleaching macroalgae composition interest) Relief recommend using classes Benthic Composition (“BROAD” > “MORPHOLOGY” > “TYPE” Relief. experienced analyst able annotate schema 120 images day.

title: TransectMeasure Workflow
text: corrections made within original annotation files ensure data consistency time. recommend following approaches ensure quality control: Check annotation points assigned values (see R scripts included GitHub repository - ‘forward-facing-benthic-composition-annotation’). Check image names match metadata sample names. Check successful deployments benthic composition data. Visually assess data trends, outliers potential errors (Figures 19 & 20). Spatially visualise data patterns distribution key habitat classes (Figure 21). >>>>> gd2md-html alert: inline image link (images/image19.png). Store image image server adjust path/filename/extension necessary. (Back top)(Next alert)>>>>> alt_text

what: Examples of publications that have used this or earlier versions of this SOP
title: TransectMeasure Workflow
code: 1.  Wilson, S. K. et al. Multiple disturbances and the global degradation of coral reefs: are reef fishes at risk or resilient? Glob. Chang. Biol. 12, 2220–2234 (2006).   2.  McLean, D. L. et al. Distribution, abundance, diversity and habitat associations of fishes across a bioregion experiencing rapid coastal development. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science 178, 36–47 (2016).   3.  McLean, D. L. et al. Using industry ROV videos to assess fish associations with subsea pipelines. Cont. Shelf Res. 141, 76–97 (2017).   4.  Bond, T. et al. The influence of depth and a subsea pipeline on fish assemblages and commercially fished species. PLoS One 13, e0207703 (2018).   5.  Bond, T. et al. Fish associated with a subsea pipeline and adjacent seafloor of the North West Shelf of Western Australia. Mar. Environ. Res. 141, 53-65 (2018).   6.  Bond, T. et al. Diel shifts and habitat associations of fish assemblages on a subsea pipeline. Fish. Res. 206, 220–234 (2018).   7.  Lester, E. et al. Drivers of variation in occurrence, abundance, and behaviour of sharks on coral reefs. Sci. Rep. 12, 728 (2022).   8.  Lester, E. et al. Relative influence of predators, competitors and seascape heterogeneity on behaviour and abundance of coral reef mesopredators. Oikos 130, 2239–2249 (2021).   9.  Rolim, F. A. et al. Network of small no-take marine reserves reveals greater abundance and body size of fisheries target species. PLoS One 14, e0204970 (2019).   10. Rolim, F. A. et al. Baited videos to assess semi-aquatic mammals: occurrence of the neotropical otter Lontra longicaudis (Carnivora: Mustelidae) in a marine coastal island in São Paulo, Southeast Brazil. Mar. Biodivers. 49, 1047-1051 (2018).   11. Haberstroh, A. J. et al. Baited video, but not diver video, detects a greater contrast in the abundance of two legal-size target species between no-take and fished zones. Mar. Biol. 169, 79 (2022).   12. Piggott, C. V. H. et al. Remote video methods for studying juvenile fish populations in challenging environments. J. Exp. Mar. Bio. Ecol. 532, 151454 (2020).   13. MacNeil, M. A. et al. Global status and conservation potential of reef sharks. Nature 583, 801–806 (2020).   14. Goetze, J. S. et al. Drivers of reef shark abundance and biomass in the Solomon Islands. PLoS One 13, e0200960 (2018).
